newsitem.title: MOROCCO: Arab Maghreb Union to cut staff -diplomat.
newsitem.headline: Arab Maghreb Union to cut staff -diplomat.

text.p: The Arab Maghreb Union, grouping five North African countries, is to cut staff at its secretariat by two-thirds because of financial problems and lack of activity, an Arab diplomat said on Monday.

The union composed of Algeria, Libya, Mauritania, Morocco and Tunisia was set up in 1989. Its secretariat headquarters was established in the Moroccan capital Rabat in 1992, headed by Tunisian national Mohamed Amamou.

"Governments of the five-country union were recently informed that the Rabat secretariat will reduce its staff to five civil servants from a total of 15...The decision taken by Amamou will be effective from May 16, 1997," the North African diplomat, who declined to be identified, told Reuters.
The move was justified by "budget problems and lack of feasable economic and social projects in the region", the diplomat said.
AMU secretariat officials were not immediately available for comment.

The AMU has been largely paralysed since December 1995 because of differences between members over issues such as Moslem fundamentalism and the Western Sahara dispute between the Algeria-backed Polisario front and Morocco over the future of the territory.

Since a U.N. embargo was imposed on Tripoli in the early 1990s, Libyan authorities declined twice to take over the union's alternating presidency in protest at what they called lack of solidarity from the other four members.
The AMU was created with the idea of forming an economic trading bloc and to strengthen cooperation between members, particularly in negotiations with their main trading partner, the European Union.
Each member contributes $350,000 a year to secretariat budget, the diplomat said.
